key_points: Twitter permanently suspended President Donald Trump's account, citing risk of incitement of violence.
The decision followed Trump's encouragement of a rally in Washington, DC, that resulted in violence and deaths.
Critics had long urged Twitter to take a firmer stance against Trump for his use of the platform to spread falsehoods and incendiary rhetoric.
Twitter had allowed controversial content from world leaders like Trump, viewing it as newsworthy, but stated such accounts are not entirely above its rules.
Before the permanent suspension, Twitter temporarily suspended Trump and warned of a permanent ban for policy violations.
Hundreds of Twitter employees had urged CEO Jack Dorsey to permanently suspend Trump.
Facebook also blocked Trump's account until at least President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration.
Trump's recent tweets were deemed to violate Twitter's Glorification of Violence policy, leading to his permanent suspension.
Critics of Trump's behavior on social media argue that actions against him are overdue.
Trump criticized Twitter's decision on the @POTUS account, but the tweets were quickly deleted.
